Description: Egyptian terracotta figure wearing festival wreath headdress, veil and earrings. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum?) coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl. 12, no. 184). Good parallel from Athribis (Tell Atrib) dated to the end of the 3rd century BC (Szmańska 2005, no.4). Naukratis parallel in Bolton Museum (1886.31.34). Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.560) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 92, no. 184, pl. 12, no. 184)
